Bacchanal through the ages: a look at Spectator’s Archives

1950s

1958: Spring Weekend “inaugurated.”

1964: First “official” Spring Weekend kicked off with a Spring Weekend committee. Activities included a carnival and boat rides, and the King’s Crown Hotel offered discounted rates for students’ dates.

1960s

1969: The dean’s office announced Spring Weekend would be postponed until the fall semester due to the “volatile situation” on campus. Protests had begun the year prior, in the spring of 1968, against the University’s involvement in the Vietnam War and the gymnasium that was to be constructed in Morningside Park.

14 February 1958

1980: First mention of “Columbiafest” appeared, ultimately becoming what the spring music event was known as in the ’80s.

1980s

16 April 1964

16 April 1984

1983: “Columbiafest” continued as a full weekend of activities involving a block party, a Hartley Jazz Festival, and a “Grand Finale Party” on Low Plaza.

1987: Columbiafest, organized by “Board of Managers,” was said to annually “include parties, concerts, a crafts fair,” and charity events sponsored by fraternities and sororities.

23 April 1998

1988: Columbiafest commenced with a balloon launch and featured performances by the Red Hot Chili Peppers and the Del Fuegos. That year’s carnival included a dunking booth on College Walk. Columbiafest ended on Sunday with Earth Day celebrations.

19 April 1988

1990: Controversy arose regarding Columbiafest funding competing with Intercultural Resource Center.

1990s

1998: Columbiafest was renamed to Bacchanal.

1999: A more robust Bacchanal was held, sponsored by Columbia College Student Council, the Engineering Student Council, and Columbia Special Events. The weeklong spring festival featured eating contests, concerts, and class wars.

21 April 1999

21 April 1999

The carnival in front of Butler Library on the last day of Bacchanal had a rock climbing wall, Bungee Run, henna artists, a chocolate factory, and games.

2000: The weeklong Bacchanal spent “nearly 3 times more money than in the past,” with a total budget of $45,000. It was called “Columbia’s first full-fledged and week-long Spring Fest.”

2000s

There was a performance by comedian Bill Bellamy on Wednesday, a foam party in Lerner Hall on Friday, and a carnival with rides, games, live music, and an additional mystery concert on Saturday.

2001: The weeklong list of activities included a foam party, eating contests, midnight games, a comedy show, and the annual carnival. Columbia Concerts, the organizers of the concert portion, went over $35,000 in debt for the Outkast performance.

28 November 2001

3 May 2002

2002: A midnight barbeque was held.

2004: Kanye West performed at the Bacchanal250 concert.

2006: Bacchanal festivities were compressed from one week to five days, but still included a carnival and “a battle-of-the-

bands” concert.

3 May 2004

2007: Bacchanal festivities no longer included a carnival or “Olympic games.”

13 April 2006

1950s

1958: Spring Weekend “inaugurated.”

1960s

1964: First “official” Spring Weekend kicked off with a Spring Weekend committee. Activities included a carnival and boat rides, and the King’s Crown Hotel offered discounted rates for students’ dates.

19 April 1988

1998: Columbiafest was renamed to Bacchanal.

1999: A more robust Bacchanal was held, sponsored by Columbia College Student Council, the Engineering Student Council, and Columbia Special Events. The weeklong spring festival featured eating contests, concerts, and class wars.

The carnival in front of Butler Library on the last day of Bacchanal had a rock climbing wall, Bungee Run, henna artists, a chocolate factory, and games.

21 April 1999

2000: The weeklong Bacchanal spent “nearly 3 times more money than in the past,” with a total budget of $45,000. It was called “Columbia’s first full-fledged and week-long Spring Fest.”

There was a performance by comedian Bill Bellamy on Wednesday, a foam party in Lerner Hall on Friday, and a carnival with rides, games, live music, and an additional mystery concert on Saturday.

2001: The weeklong list of activities included a foam party, eating contests, midnight games, a comedy show, and the annual carnival. Columbia Concerts, the organizers of the concert portion, went over $35,000 in debt for the Outkast performance.
